title: Why do we need to write essays? - Quora

response.answer_text: It is, as others have said, to teach you to present ‘arguments’ in a logical, coherent and consistent fashion; not some mindless diatribe. However, why do we educate the young in the way that we do? Essay writing is but one tool in our drive to educate. We could educate you in: how to make a comfortable dwelling in a cave; how to hunt large herbivores without being killed yourself; how to make fire with three sticks and a piece of string; how to spot the ‘above ground’ manifestations of edible tubers. However, we do not. We educate you with a combination of 400 year old physics, literature so old that it has passed into the ‘out of copyright’ zone, mathematics so easy a child of three could manage it and history so anodyne as to be worthless. We do this to spark interest as well as providing the tools you may need in the modern world. If but one percent of the children we educate become physicists, chemists, historians, mathematicians, economists, doctors, dentists (I would include lawyers but . . .), is that not justification enough for you having to write an essay? Universal education did not happen before the twentieth century; you should think yourself lucky that you get to write an essay. Most people prior did not have the oppurtunity.

The process that you take in writing an essay helps with critical thinking. It’s just that most schools don’t just blatantly say this. Writing an essay can also give you a view that you haven’t had before. It can completely change your whole perception of an object. It takes a lot of effort to write a good essay so it could also help with organization of paragraphs and your use of rhetoric.
